Cabinet Committee on the Coal Industry.The Cabinet Committee had reached the conclu-sion that it was impossible to refrain at thepresent juncture from Government action of some kind. They had therefore agreed that the PrimeMinister himself should announce, in the course ofthe Debate that afternoon, that the government intended to introduce a Bill to suspend the SevenofHours Act for a terny( probably five) years, whichwould enable eight hours to be worked. They also,proposed the introduction of an "omnibus" Billembracing a number of the recommendations of theCoal Commission on the re-organisation of theindustry. In announcing this, the Government wouldtake their stand on the proposals of a month ago(Paper CP.-202 (26)) .As regards mining royalties the Prime minister proposed to point out that a new situation had arisen since the Government accepted the Reportof the Coal Commission. Neither of the parties tothe dispute had accepted the Report or the Govern-menfs proposals, and the strike had taken place.In consequence, the Government considered themselvesentirely free in this matter.As regards the suspension of the Seven HoursAct, he proposed to point out that it was made clear in the Report that some sacrifice from theminers was necessary, "and the Government hadconvinced themselves that the least onerous sacrifice was in the direction of an increase inhours. The reason why the Government had made no suggestion in this direction hitherto was thatthey had felt that they could not introduce legis-lation in regard to a lengthening of hours until they had assurances from, the owners that the con-cessions by the miners would be small.(At this point the Prime Ministerhanded round copies of CP.-239(26) (Appendix) , which contains a statement of the assurancesaccepted by representatives ofthe Mining Association at a meetingthe previous afternoon with theSecretary of State for War, theMinister of Labour and theSecretary for Mines.)In the course of the discussion a number of amendments were suggested to the "above statement,mainly with the object of making it unmistakeablyclear to the miners that there would be no reduction-tion in their wages below the minimum of 1921.It was pointed out that if substantial, alterationswere made in the draft statement the mine-owners would have to be asked to agree to them.The Cabinet approved the general lines of the policy proposed bythe Prime Minister and summarised above, and left the Prime minister himself to make such commentary ashe thought fit in order to make clear the precise significance ofthe mine-owners' assurances.tehall Gardens, S.W.1,June 15, 1926 .
